children.subject: +1, congrats on all your acceptances! would also super appreciate it if you could share your gpa/background

Thanks for the congratulations, I really appreciate it! I bet you guys will do great in your future grad schools applications! :)

Sure, I would be happy to provide some background information! My overall GPA was 3.89, with a CS GPA of 3.82. As of now, I am in my third semester of research - so by the time that I submitted most of my applications back in the Fall, I had completed 1 semester of research and was in the middle of my second semester of research. I have not yet published any papers, but I will soon be publishing one - however, when I submitted most of my applications, in those applications I did not mention that I was going to soon be publishing that first paper because at the time of my application submissions I was not yet planning on submitting that paper in the future. 

In case this is helpful, in terms of my letters of recommendation, I had 1 letter of recommendation from "industry" (my manager from an internship), and 2 letters of recommendation from professors (1 of them was involved with some of my research, and 1 of them I had TA'ed for).

I've also had 2 software engineering internships at a pretty large company, and I have been a TA 3 times (with my third semester being this current semester).

I hope that this is helpful! I was in the same exact position that you both were in when I was starting the application process - I didn't know how successful my applications would be. My advice would be to just do your best, don't worry or overstress too much, and I think it really will all work out in the end. 

Let me know if you have any more questions! I'd be really glad to help :)

Wow, congrats on the acceptances, I hope to be in your position someday. Do you mind sharing your GPA/background (any research experience, papers published)? It would be so helpful since several of these schools (like Columbia) don't publish stats for admitted CS MS students.

I hope this is not an impolite ask, since this is an anonymous forum. Thank you so much!

I'm an undergrad as well. Maybe there's value in seeing how CS (research, teaching, etc) is done at other highly ranked schools after spending 3-4 years at Berkeley. (many of OPs schools are still highly ranked. those out-of-state publics are definitely top 10 CS schools).

Currently an undergrad so take my opinion with a grain of salt: personally I would stay at Berkeley for 5th year masters. It seems to be the cheapest, and it is also a research focused master program. Just curious, what was the reasoning for applying to MS programs at UCLA, UT Austin, UCI, UMich, Georgia Tech? A couple of my upperclassmen friends who applied to MS programs mentioned that it wouldn't really be worth to go to a "lower ranked" school if you're already graduating from Berkeley, as its marginal benefit won't really make an impact. Congrats on all your acceptances!

Current 5th year MS student here. Congrats on all your admissions! Selecting between all those excellent options is a good problem to have :)

IMO, it all comes down to one question: what do you want to get out of your master's degree? There's surely some reason -- probably multiple -- why you're deciding to spend an extra 1-2 years in school. What are they? I'd encourage you to let this (and of course any hard constraints like cost) guide your decision.

Do you want extra time doing research to further help (or decide if you even want to submit) a PhD application down the road? 5th year MS could be a good choice since it's more or less a continuation of what you're currently doing here, and you wouldn't have to worry about adjusting to a new school. Doubly so if you want a shorter program, since most are 2 years, not 1.

Are you just looking to take some extra courses, and maybe live in a different part of the US? Consider the options you have from outside CA (although if you're not from SoCal, UCLA/Irvine can probably give you that experience too).

Do you have interest in continuing to teach? I don't know what the options look like at other schools, but that's something you can look into.

Best of luck with your decision!

I’m still definitely open to attending Brown if I get a chance to learn more about it, but my thoughts were that if I was going to pay the cost of an Ivy League school, I might as well go to Columbia which is “ranked higher” overall and for CS graduate school (take that with a grain of salt, I don’t know how much rankings really matter), and is in Manhattan, which in my opinion would provide for a much more interesting and exciting day to day life experience than Providence, Rhode Island. As I am potentially interested in working in the fintech/financial industry after grad school, being in NYC is also a potential advantage too as it might make it easier to make connections in that industry. Also, some of my high school friends will be attending grad school in Manhattan, and would be around a 10 minute drive away from Columbia, so while I know I shouldn’t give this factor too much weight, I think that could also be a lot of fun. 

If you or anyone here knows anything about Brown and would be willing to provide me with information on it, I’d really appreciate it!

Also, if you think any of my reasons are not really “valid” reasons or I should stop considering them as reasons, I’d really be glad to hear that feedback! I won’t take it personally or anything, but I think it could be helpful to hear whether people think some of these reasons might be too “superficial”.

I also have been interested in the fintech/financial industry. I think there's a big difference between the two—fintech is stuff like Chime, Robinhood, Stripe, Acorns, etc. and financial services could be stuff like big banks (Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, etc.) or trading firms (Jane Street, D.E. Shaw, etc.) or hedge funds (Two Sigma, etc.). I would argue you'd be at a disadvantage leaving the bay if you're pursuing fintech as these are fundamentally tech companies and thus engrained in SV, and from my own experience, you're at no advantage being in Manhattan for the financial services firms beyond having less flight time to onsites. 

Personally, Brown looks like a really interesting place to be—I love what I hear about the campus culture, and living in Providence seems like a fun two years in a small college town that you probably wouldn't get to do any other time (whereas Manhattan you could always do). 

I can't speak for rankings—but I do think that Brown is definitely "good enough" and you wouldn't be at a disadvantage (recruiting or PHD wise at least). HS Friends is definitely a good plus for Columbia though.
Out of curiosity, why are you not considering Brown?

I would say pick Berkeley if you end up getting in. It's a research based program vs just coursework focused, which is really the draw of graduate school and will help you know if doing a PhD is something you want. Also 1 year vs 2 years means less commitment for the same degree, though you can always continue with a PhD or independent research if you like what you're doing. Finally, it's cheaper and "ranked higher" (I'm personally not a big fan of ranking, but it does say something about the accomplishment of professors here).
OP - where did you decide to go finally for your MS?

history.content:
Hey everyone, I hope you're all doing well! I am planning on getting a CS MS starting Fall 2021, and I was wondering if anyone would be able to give me some advice on my decision!

I have been accepted to the CS MS programs at Columbia, Brown, UCLA, UT Austin, UIUC, UC Irvine, and the University of Michigan (I'm still waiting on a few more schools, i.e., Berkeley 5th Year EECS MS, Cornell, and Georgia Tech). The universities I am currently mainly considering, of the ones I have already been admitted to, are Columbia, UCLA, UT Austin, UIUC and UC Irvine. I'm having trouble finding concrete advantages/disadvantages that some of these schools have in relation to each other so that I can have tangible reasons for filtering some of the schools out and coming to a decision. I was wondering if anyone might have any insights/opinions, from personal experiences or from friends, about any of these schools and/or their CS programs, specifically graduate programs but undergraduate information also could be helpful) that you would be willing to share. Columbia, UT Austin, and UIUC, and UC Irvine have coursework only options (without research), and separate research options, and at UCLA you do a research thesis/project. Cost is definitely one factor (Columbia comes out to be around $57,000 more expensive than UT Austin and UIUC, and about $45,000 more than UCLA, and UC Irvine would turn out to essentially be free because of a scholarship offer), but I don't want to base my decision solely, or extremely heavily on cost, as Columbia has some advantages the other schools do not (located in NYC, near Wall Street, as I am potentially interested in, but definitely not certain about, going into the fintech/financial industry after getting my Master's degree).

Any input, no matter how small, would be sincerely appreciated! Thanks so very much! :)
history.subject: Request for advice on making a decision between CS MS programs
